project.name: Infusion pump air-in-line hazard assurance case
project.description:
Assurance case example: air-in-line hazard for infusion pump device.

Argument developed in NOR-STA for assuance case training

Argevide
2020

node.name: Infusion hazards are mitigated
node.description:
The infusion pump case study is based on „Open Patient-Controlled Analgesia Infusion Pump System Requirements” published by SAnToS research group at Kansas State University. See openpcapump.santoslab.org for more details.
The case study is limited to one hazard: air in line
Hazard analysis is based on FDA publication "Guidance for Industry and FDA Staff - Total Product Life Cycle: Infusion Pump - Premarket Notification [510(k)] Submissions" available at http://www.fda.gov/MedicalDevices/DeviceRegulationandGuidance/GuidanceDocuments/ucm206153.htm

node.name: Infusion hazards are mitigated
Safety demonstrated by mitigating infusion hazards
node.label: S0

node.name: One hazard identified in this simplified argument
node.label: J0
node.description: You can find more information on infusion pump hazards in FDA publication "Guidance for Industry and FDA Staff - Total Product Life Cycle: Infusion Pump - Premarket Notification [510(k)] Submissions" available at http://www.fda.gov/MedicalDevices/DeviceRegulationandGuidance/GuidanceDocuments/ucm206153.htm

node.label: F1

node.description: System hazard log describes all identified hazards.

node.name: System Description.docx
node.label: Ev2

node.name: Air in Line hazard (H1) has been mitigated
node.label: G1

node.name: Air in line hazard description
node.description:
One of the infusion pump hazards is „air in line”. The hazard occurs when air bubbles are present in the intravenous line and delivered to the patient bloodstream.
The hazard is desribed in FDA document.
Small bubbles in bloodstream can block capillaries in vital organs, most urgently the brain, causing anything from pain and inflammation to neurological damage and paralysis. Big bubbles can fill the heart and make it compressing the air instead of pumping the blood. It’s estimated that 200–300 cm3 of air in bloodstream would probably kill the patient.

node.name: Argument by referring to hazard controls
node.label: S1.1
node.description: Preventive, detective and corrective (reactive) controls have been identified and defined during hazard analysis.

node.name: Hazard controls have been identified during adequate Hazard Analysis
node.label: J1.1
node.description:
Preventive, detective and corrective controls have been identified during Hazard Analysis and their adequacy has been justified.
Adequacy of Hazard Analysis results is demonstrated elsewhere.

node.name: Clinician manual.pdf

node.name: Clinician manual and training ensures sealed delivery path
node.label: F1.1.3
node.description:
The clinician authenticates themselves, the patient, and the liquid pain-killer received from the hospital pharmacy, loads the drug, attaches a flexible tube leading to a needle, primes the tube and needle to remove air, and inserts the needle into the patient.
It's the clinician duty to expel air from tube and needle before treatment.

assessment.comment: Test cover all operation modes. Test results positive and verified.
Test cover all operation modes. Test results positive and verified.
